om.stdcomponent
Class EquationComponent

java.lang.Object
  om.stdquestion.QComponent
      om.stdcomponent.EquationComponent

public class EquationComponent
extends QComponent

Represents equations that are produced as bitmaps. Uses a LaTeX-like format that isn't sensitive to whitespace; supports a very, very small subset of what LaTeX can do.

If the equation is simple enough to be displayed in plain XHTML, use TextEquationComponent instead.

Format examples

(These examples are intended to show everything we support.)
  • x+y=z
    Simple text. Variables (letters) will be made italic
  • x^2
    Superscript
  • x_1
    Subscript
  • x^{2y}
    Subscript with more than one character
  • x^1_3
    Subscript and superscript on same thing
  • ^1_3
    Subscript and superscript on their own rather than being attached to a letter, e.g. for atomic numbers
  • \frac{3}{4}
    Fraction (3/4 in this case)
  • \sqrt{x^2}
    Square root
  • \sin y
    Displays some standard functions so they don't come out in italics
  • \mbox{text with space}
    Displays text non-italic with whitespace
  • \sum_{i=1}^{10}
    Sum from i=1 to 10
  • \int_{i=1}^{10}
    Integral from i=1 to 10
  • \Delta x = 2 \pi r
    Include any Greek letter, upper-case ones as shown. Must have space after letter name, i.e. \Deltax or \pir would confuse it.
  • \textstyle\sum_{i=1}^{10}
    Sum from i=1 to 10, but using the style it would normally use inside a fraction (with limits to the right rather than above/below). The full set of textsize-changing constants are \displaystyle (= the normal 'outer' size), \textstyle (in one level of fractions), \scriptstyle (super/subscript), and \scriptscriptstyle.
  • \left( i^2 \right)
    Use 'stretchy brackets' that get taller to match their content. You need to pair \left and \right, but the symbols after them don't have to match. Available symbols are ( ) { } [ ] | and . - this last doesn't display at all, so it can be used when you don't really want a matching \right.

XML usage

<equation alt="z squared = x squared plus y squared">z^2=x^2+y^2</equation>

Properties

PropertyValuesEffect
id(string)Specifies unique ID
display(boolean)Includes in/removes from output
enabled(boolean)Activates/deactivates children
alt(string)Alternative text for those who can't read the bitmap
textfont(boolean)Uses default text font instead of the equation font

Contents

You can put other things within equations using <eplace> tags. At the point in your equation that you'd like to include something, do <eplace width="100" height="50" label="Numerator">...Om component/s...</place>. A few components (currently just EditFieldComponent) are capable of estimating their own width and height, so you can leave out width and height if what you're putting in is one of these. The label is used for accessibility and should probably be a repeat of something from the equation's alt text (so you can tell which bit of the equation it is). You may also include a for= attribute for the label, which makes it apply to a specific component; otherwise it by default applies to any single labelable component inside the <eplace>.

defineProperties

protected void defineProperties()
                         throws OmDeveloperException
Description copied from class: QComponent
Intended for overriding. Default allows 'id' and 'display', so do remember to call superclass if you override or you won't get these.

Basically call defineProperty a bunch of times to set up all your properties. If you wish to set initial property values you can do that here too.

initChildren

protected void initChildren(org.w3c.dom.Element eThis)
                     throws OmException
Description copied from class: QComponent
Initialises children based on the given XML element.

This default implementation treats all child elements as components. If you want to include text as well or treat elements differently (if they have a specific meaning for your components) you need to override this method. QDocument.buildInside() and similar will be useful; or you may wish to call initAsText.

Overrides:
initChildren in class QComponent
Parameters:
eThis - XML element representing this component
Throws:
OmException - If there's an error initialising the children

setEquation

public void setEquation(java.lang.String sEquation,
                        java.lang.String sAlt)
                 throws OmDeveloperException
Sets the equation to a different value.

Note that you cannot change equations that include placeholder <eplace> tags; nor can you add these to an equation that doesn't have them. Please scream viscerally at sam, while jabbing a pin threateningly toward your voodoo doll, if you require this feature.

However, you may find that simple text placeholders of the __A__ variety, which are supported and which can include LaTeX-like content if necessary, are sufficient for your needs.

Parameters:
sEquation - New value for equation content
sAlt - New value for screenreader alternative
Throws:
OmDeveloperException - If you try to change an equation that has placeholder XML tags

produceVisibleOutput

public void produceVisibleOutput(QContent qc,
                                 boolean bInit,
                                 boolean bPlain)
                          throws OmException
Description copied from class: QComponent
Builds up content of this component that should end up in question output. Only called if the 'display' property is set to true.

Default implementation just calls produceChildOutput().

produceVisibleOutput in class QComponent
Parameters:
qc - Output variable that accepts question content
bInit - True if this is first call in question initialisation
Throws:
